Award.AwardTitle: Organic electronic devices using epitaxially grown conjugated polymer crystalline nanowires on carbon nanotube and graphene electrodes

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a novel approach for the fabrication of high performance organic field effect transistors by exploiting strong pi-pi interaction between the polymer chains and the polymer-electrodes for both efficient charge injection and transport. The approach is via epitaxial growth of conjugated crystalline polymer nanowires on the single walled carbon nanotubes and graphene electrodes.

Organic transistors will be fabricated via direct growth of crystalline poly (3-hexylthiophene) and poly(3,3-didodecylquaterthiophene) nanowires on the carbon nanotubes and graphene electrodes and their charge transport properties will be studied. The proposed transistors will have the following specific advantages: (i) crystalline polymer nanowires will have improved nanomorphology, (ii) strong pi-pi interaction between electrodes and semiconducting materials will provide improved charge injection, (iii) higher on-current and operational frequency will make them suitable for high frequency operation, and (iv) owing to reduced contact resistance and better channel morphology, nanoscale transistors will be demonstrated without any short channel effect.

The successful demonstration of high performance polymer nanowires based organic transistors will have significant impact in low cost plastic electronics including flexible displays, sensor sheets, radiofrequency identification tags, and photovoltaics. Education and outreach activities includes, (i) interdisciplinary training of graduate, undergraduate and high school students, (ii) integration of research results in a new graduate level course through lecture and lab demonstration, (iii) minority students recruitment through UCF Office of Diversity Initiative and Women?s Research Center and (iv) outreach to local high schools through visits and to the community through website and news letters.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF funded research, we developed novel approaches for the fabrication of Organic field effect transistors (OFETs) via epitaxial growth of highly crystalline organic semiconductors (OSCs) on carbon nanotube and graphene electrodes. OFETs has been considered as a promising active  elements in the large area, low-cost, and low-weight electronic devices such as flexible integrated circuits, displays, sensor arrays, and radio-frequency identification tags. For many of these applications, OFETs should operate at high switching speed with a high on-current. A major bottleneck in fabricating high performance OFET is the large interfacial barrier between conventional metal electrodes (gold, palladium) and organic semiconductors, which results in a low charge injection from the metal electrode to OSC and limits the performance of OFETs. The large interface barrier can be originated from discontinuity in morphology, interfacial dipole barrier, and Schottky barrier. Additionally, the improvements of morphology of the OSC can improve the charge transport resulting in a high performance OFETs.

 In this project, we carried out (i) detailed and systematic study of the growth of OSC on carbon nanotubes and graphene, (ii) fabricated OFETs using carbon nanotubes and graphene as electrodes, (iii) studied the room temperature and low temperature charge transport properties of the fabricated devices. We found that the OFETs with carbon nanotubes and graphene electrodes have significantly higher mobility, on-current and current on-off ration in comparison to control devices fabricated with metal electrode. We also found that the charge injection barrier between carbon nanotubes and OSC is significantly lower than the metal electrodes. Owing to the improved charge injection barrier, the short channel OFETs show an operating frequency of 211 MHz which is significantly higher than that of previously reported values. We attribute the improved device performance due to the high work function of carbon nanotubes and graphene, and strong π-π interaction with organic molecules which can reduce the injection barrier at the electrode/organic interface.

 In our educational activity, four graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and several high school students received training. Participants received training on the material growth, state of the art micro/nano device fabrication, electrical and optical characterizations, report and paper writing and presentation skills. Four Ph.D., and one undergraduate thesis was resulted from this project. Among the participants, two graduate students were female fulfilling NSF’s requirement of broadening participation in STEM education. The project contributed 11 published peer reviewed papers and the students were coauthor of these papers. Students also presented their works at various national and regional meetings. The research done through this project has been integrated to graduate teaching though courses such as “Physics of NanoElectronic Devices”, and “Introduction to nanoscience and nanotechnology”. Outreach to K-16 students were done by hosting lab demonstration to students of UCF Summer Research Academy, lab visits, demonstration at local libraries through “NanoFest”, iNano workshop, hosting events at Orlando science center, Chemistry Olympiads and publishing newsletters.

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2015
Modified by: Saiful I Khondaker
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this NSF funded research, we developed novel approaches for the fabrication of Organic field effect transistors (OFETs) via epitaxial growth of highly crystalline organic semiconductors (OSCs) on carbon nanotube and graphene electrodes. OFETs has been considered as a promising active elements in the large area, low-cost, and low-weight electronic devices such as flexible integrated circuits, displays, sensor arrays, and radio-frequency identification tags. For many of these applications, OFETs should operate at high switching speed with a high on-current. A major bottleneck in fabricating high performance OFET is the large interfacial barrier between conventional metal electrodes (gold, palladium) and organic semiconductors, which results in a low charge injection from the metal electrode to OSC and limits the performance of OFETs. The large interface barrier can be originated from discontinuity in morphology, interfacial dipole barrier, and Schottky barrier. Additionally, the improvements of morphology of the OSC can improve the charge transport resulting in a high performance OFETs. In this project, we carried out (i) detailed and systematic study of the growth of OSC on carbon nanotubes and graphene, (ii) fabricated OFETs using carbon nanotubes and graphene as electrodes, (iii) studied the room temperature and low temperature charge transport properties of the fabricated devices. We found that the OFETs with carbon nanotubes and graphene electrodes have significantly higher mobility, on-current and current on-off ration in comparison to control devices fabricated with metal electrode. We also found that the charge injection barrier between carbon nanotubes and OSC is significantly lower than the metal electrodes. Owing to the improved charge injection barrier, the short channel OFETs show an operating frequency of 211 MHz which is significantly higher than that of previously reported values. We attribute the improved device performance due to the high work function of carbon nanotubes and graphene, and strong π-π interaction with organic molecules which can reduce the injection barrier at the electrode/organic interface. In our educational activity, four graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and several high school students received training. Participants received training on the material growth, state of the art micro/nano device fabrication, electrical and optical characterizations, report and paper writing and presentation skills. Four Ph.D., and one undergraduate thesis was resulted from this project. Among the participants, two graduate students were female fulfilling NSFÆs requirement of broadening participation in STEM education. The project contributed 11 published peer reviewed papers and the students were coauthor of these papers. Students also presented their works at various national and regional meetings. The research done through this project has been integrated to graduate teaching though courses such as "Physics of NanoElectronic Devices", and "Introduction to nanoscience and nanotechnology". Outreach to K-16 students were done by hosting lab demonstration to students of UCF Summer Research Academy, lab visits, demonstration at local libraries through "NanoFest", iNano workshop, hosting events at Orlando science center, Chemistry Olympiads and publishing newsletters.
